pages.text: Thylacocercus ignota comes from the middle Cambrian, with fossils found in the Wheeler Shale, Utah (US). It is a small vetulocystid, growing up to 2 cm in height. Thylacocercus is unique from its older relatives by the fact that cones present are now gone, with the dorsal 'mouth' cone now replaced by a mouth surrounded by a crown of tentacles, although it is unknown what

became of the posterior cone, due to the fact we only have a singular fossil to work from, meaning it is most likely on the 'obscured' side of the fossil. The generic name derives from the Greek words 'thylacos', to mean 'bag-like'; and 'kerkus', to mean 'tail-like'. The specific name derives from the Greek word 'ignotus', to mean 'unknown'.
